The Japanese writing system uses pictoral characters to convey meaning. It contains 3 major sets of characters: Hirigana, Katakana and Kanji. 
 
 Hirigana is a basic alphabet which contains characters each depicting an individual syllable such as ka or me. 
 
 Katakana is similar to hirigana, but contains slightly different characters, but you can see the similarity. The purpose of katakana is to write words that are taken from foreign languages like computer or beer. 
 
 Kanji are more complex, and there a lot more of them than the basic kana. Kanji are characters from the chinese alphabet that have been given japanese meanings. They are characters that convey meaning through a picture depiction. For example the kanji for horse looks like an ancient artists rendition of a horse. Kanji are usually built up for multiple syllables and can be combined with other kanji for different meanings. 
 
 You can use combinations of hirigana to spell the pronunciation of kanji. Kanji have two different pronunciations, onyomi and kunyomi. Onyomi is the chinese pronunciation and kunyomi is the Japanese. Kunyomi is generally used for stand alone kanji and onyomi is generally used for combined kanji. Kanji are used wherever possible but there are still some words that need to be spelt with hirigana and katakana. 
 
 There is a set way of writing kana which are based on a few rules that determine stroke order. Strokes should be left to write and top to bottom, prioritising horizontal strokes.
 
 The sections of this app are designed to help study hirigana and katakana with an interactive test. 
 
 Good luck and have fun!
